bestBHT.bht: The things that defile a person extend beyond ceremonial impurity to encompass moral impurity as well. Striving for holiness is crucial, as actions that are inconsistent with holiness are considered common and profane. Such actions bring defilement to both the body and soul, resulting in guilt and exposing one to everlasting punishment. Conversely, eating with unwashed hands does not defile a person nor transgress any divine laws. Only through the blood of Christ can we be cleansed from the pollution and guilt of our actions, securing us from the punishment we rightfully deserve.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: These are the things which defile a man: but to eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man—Thus does our Lord sum up this whole searching discourse.
THE WOMAN OF CANAAN AND HER DAUGHTER.
John Calvin: Instead of the verb pollute, the Greek term is κοινοῖ, make common.
Everything that was inconsistent with this holiness was called common, that is, profane.
[It] is a mode of speaking peculiar to the Hebrews.
Philip Schaff: Ceremonial impurity is insignificant compared with moral impurity.
Yet Christians now are as slow to learn this as the disciples were.
These are the things which defile the man.
John Gill: These are the things which defile a man... they bring a defilement on the whole man, both body and soul, fasten guilt upon him, and expose him to everlasting punishment.

To eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man... he contracts no filth to his soul hereby, nor any guilt to his conscience; nor does he break any law of God; nor is he liable to any penalty for such an omission.

The things before mentioned are in their nature evil... they render men loathsome and odious to the divine being; and expose them to shame and ruin; and it is only the blood of Christ can cleanse them from the pollution and guilt of them, and secure them from that punishment they deserve.

Ceremonial impurity is insignificant compared with moral impurity, yet Christians are slow to learn this. Instead of polluting oneself, one should strive for holiness, for the things that are inconsistent with holiness are considered common and profane. These actions bring a defilement on the whole person, body, and soul, fastening guilt and exposing one to everlasting punishment. However, not eating with unwashed hands does not defile a person, as it does not contract filth to their soul or break any law of God. Only the blood of Christ can cleanse us from the pollution and guilt of our actions, securing us from the punishment we deserve.
